prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Resolved background CO(2-1) emission
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Image CO(2-1) transition at maximum resolution to resolve the Einstein ring and allow for spatially resolved CO(2-1) to CO(4-3) and CO(6-5) line ratio analysis.
Test the detectability of the possible tidal tail in the North-East in highly smoothed spectral imaging.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The target source has been observed by ALMA in Cycle-0. Its morphology consists of three knots, with the faintest appearing in the Nort-West. Its measured fluxes are the reference to estimate the requested sensitivity. We consider the knots to be point-like down to a resolution of 0.3arcsec as evidenced by JVLA observations, thus we do not correct for a narrower resolution requested in this proposal. We consider AOT default weather conditions.
The CO(2-1) transition fluxes had to be measured in the clean component map, as a result of the poor resolution yielding a quasi unresolved emission (Figure 2). The faintest knot shows a line peak of ~3.5mJy and a line FWHM~460km/s. In order to balance proposal time and knot detectability, we request a sensitivity of 0.7mJy (5sigma detection) with a spectral resolution of 20km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(2-1) isotopes to calibrate molecular gas masses in background system
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Target CO(2-1) isotopes at least in the brightest of the three knots, appearing in the South.
Additional molecular species which fall in the proposed spectral setup are: SiO(5-4), CS(4-3) and C34S(4-3).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The target source has been observed by ALMA in Cycle-0. Its morphology consists of three knots, with the faintest appearing in the Nort-West. While its measured fluxes are the reference for the other science goals, here we adopt as reference the brightest of the knots, appearing in the South, due to the faintness of the targeted transitions. We consider the knot to be point-like down to a resolution of 0.3arcsec as evidenced by JVLA observations, thus we do not correct for a narrower resolution requested in this proposal. We consider AOT default weather conditions.
From the ZSpec spectrum (Figure 2) we identify a ~2sigma detection (8.8+-4.2 Jy.km/s) of a channel corresponding to isotopes of background C18O(5-4) and foreground 13CO(3-2) and C18O(3-2). 13CO(5-4) seems to fall where the spectrum is faulty. Comparing to the channel where together background CO(5-4) and foreground CO(3-2) fall, we can estimate background isotopes abundance.
First, we assume the channel tracing together foreground 12CO(3-2) and background 12CO(5-4), is mostly dominated by background emission assuming conservatively that the 12CO(4-3) intensity is equal to that of 12CO(5-4) intensity (usually, 12CO(5-4) is more intense in SMGs, Carilli & Walter 2013).
This also implies that the "isotopes-channel" has to be dominated by background C18O(5-4) emission. This is, if we assume foreground 12CO to 13CO and C18O intensity ratios of, respectively, 10 and 30, typical values observed in central regions of normal and IR-bright galaxies (e.g., Paglione et al. 2001, Tan et al. 2011), the foreground isotope fluxes are negligible compared to the total flux of the channel. Hence, 12CO to C18O J:5-4 intensity ratio is expected to be smaller than 4.5+-2.3, ie, 6.8 in the worst case.
Applying a 6.8 correction to the knot 12CO(2-1) line peaks, we request a sensitivity of 0.23mJy at a spectral resolution of 86 km/s, yielding, in a worst case scenario, a ~10sigma detection in the south knot (line peak at ~2.3mJy), a ~5.6sigma detection in the Nort-East knot (~1.3mJy), and a ~2.2sigma detection in the Nort-West knot (~0.5mJy).
We believe the 2sigma detection of this isotope channel is real, for the following reason: CI 3P1-3P0 and CS(10-9) lines are detected in two channels of the ZSpec spectrum (at ~242GHz, Figure 2) also at the 2sigma level with a combined flux of 14.1+-5.5 Jy.km/s. Value which is very much in agreement with that observed by ALMA in Cycle-0 (14.2+-2.0 Jy.km/s).
The spectral resolution of 86km/s still allows to resolve the two CO(5-4) isotope lines, which are at a velocity separation of ~1140km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Background CO(4-3) to constrain lens model
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
With evidence for foreground absorption critically affecting the lens modelling at near-IR wavelengths, the millimetre range is the ideal spectral region to analyse the lens model.
We thus wish to observe the CO(4-3) at a deeper level and with higher-resolution than in Cycle-0 in order to better constrain the lens model. The current model (as analysed by lensview) shows evidence for the presence of the North-East tail observed in HST-F110W imaging, but the overall model still fails to provide a good quality fit (currently chi2/v ~ 3). We wish to improve the lens model and confirm the tidal tail candidate observe in near-IR imaging.
Detect the forbidden atomic Carbon 3P1-3P0 transition.
Test the detection of foreground continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The target source has been observed by ALMA in Cycle-0. Its morphology consists of three knots, with the faintest appearing in the Nort-West. Its measured fluxes are the reference to estimate the requested sensitivity. We consider the knots to be point-like down to a resolution of 0.3arcsec as evidenced by JVLA observations, thus we do not correct for a narrower resolution requested in this proposal. We consider AOT default weather conditions.
The Cycle-0 observation of CO(4-3) yields a line-peak flux of 15.5mJy in the North-West knot. Given the need to have high signal-to-noise to better constrain the lens model and to test the presence of the tidal tail in the North-East, we request a sensitivity of 0.77mJy with a 20km/s spectral resolution (yielding a detection level of 20sigma).
The requested resolution is also necessary to avoid blending with a possible foreground continuum detection.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Background CO(6-5) to constrain CO SLED and lens model
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Target CO(6-5) transition to constrain the intermediate-J part of the CO SLED, before attempt even higher J transitions.
The high-resolution and requested sensitivity will also allow to constrain the lens model together with CO(4-3) and assess the spatial distribution of CO(6-5) to CO(2-1) and CO(4-3) intensity ratios.
Test the detection of foreground continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The target source has been observed by ALMA in Cycle-0. Its morphology consists of three knots, with the faintest appearing in the Nort-West. Its measured fluxes are the reference to estimate the requested sensitivity. We consider the knots to be point-like down to a resolution of 0.3arcsec as evidenced by JVLA observations, thus we do not correct for a narrower resolution requested in this proposal. We consider AOT default weather conditions.
The CO(6-5) transition has not been observed by any observatory so far in this source. Hence, we assume typical CO(4-3) to CO(1-0) luminosity ratios observed for SMGs (0.46, Table 2 in Carilli & Walter 2013), and, conservatively, the lowest CO(6-5) to CO(1-0) intensity ratio observed in SMGs so far (6, Figure 4 in Carilli & Walter 2013). This yields a CO(6-5) to CO(4-3) intensity ratio of 0.83. As a result, comparing with the requested sensitivity in the CO(4-3) science goal, we request a sensitivity of 0.64mJy at a spectral resolution of 27km/s.
The requested resolution is also necessary to avoid blending with a possible foreground continuum detection.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NH3 in absorption at foreground redshift
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Target the candidate absorption feature observed in the ZSPEC spectrum at 265GHz. Four NH3 transitions are found close to this frequency. This molecule is known to have a higher sensitivity to variations in the proton-to-electron mass ratio compared to other molecules (Flambaud & Kozlov 2007). This science goal aims at identification of absorption lines and establish a flux reference for future higher spectral resolution observations, required to reach enough precision to establish strong limits on the proton-to-electron mass ratio variation with cosmic time.
Test the detectability of CH3OH lines falling in the setup, a molecule expected to be even more sensitive to variations in the proton-to-electron mass ratio than NH3 (Jansen et al. 2011).
Ultimately, we will also target the other absorption feature detected in the ZSpec spectrum at 300GHz, possibly induced by H2CO absorption. This molecule has been used in comparison with NH3 to establish limits in the proton-to-electron mass ratio variation (Kanekar 2011).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The target source has been observed by ALMA in Cycle-0. Its morphology consists of three knots, with the brightest appearing in the South and partly crossing the disc of the foreground galaxy. This knot is the best candidate to search for foreground absorption in its line-of-sight. We consider AOT default weather conditions.
The ZSpec spectrum shows a peak line depth of ~10mJy. Given the uncertainty on the molecular line responsible for the absorption, and if it is just one or more, we request a 0.5mJy sensitivity at a 35km/s spectral resolution (yielding a 20sigma detection) to comply with the science goal aims.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The chance alignment of a massive galaxy with a background source, producing a flux and spatial magnification of the latter, gives the opportunity to study galaxy properties at a detail level usually far from observatory capabilities. This proposal focuses on one gravitational lens system selected in the Herschel-ATLAS as a bright (S_500um = 227mJy) 160um-``peaker'' source. The target was observed in Cycle-0 and with what the team has learned so far with the delievered and ancillary data, we propose: spatially resolved observations of the CO J:2-1, J:4-3, and J:6-5 to improve the lens modelling, confirm the detection of a tidal tail also observed at 1.1um, and constrain the spatially resolved CO SLED; observation of the 13CO and C18O isotopes to calibrate molecular gas mass estimates (this is one of the three science goals, among five, not delievered to the team in Cycle-0); target the ZSpec-detected foreground absorption feature associated with Ammonia, a molecular line known to be very sensitive to variations in the proton-to-electron mass ratio accross cosmic time.
This proposal is part of the PhD project of Gustavo Orellana (PI 2011.0.00476.S targeting this same galaxy).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
